webTitle: Madame Tussauds owner prepares for multibillion pound flotation

fields.standfirst: Merlin Entertainments, owned by Lego family trust and Blackstone and CVC, expects to raise £800m in share offer
fields.body:
The owner of Madame Tussauds waxworks and the Legoland theme parks has launched the latest in a new wave of London flotations, in a move that will value the stakes of its private equity backers at billions of pounds.

Merlin Entertainments, which is 98% owned by the Lego family trust Kirkbi and the buyout firms Blackstone and CVC, said it plans to raise up to £800m via the share offer that will value it at up to £3.34bn.

The move is the latest in what is being seen as a revival in the London flotations market, coming after the privatisation of Royal Mail where investors have immediately made large profits. London has seen 61 flotations so far this year, according to the analyst firm Dealogic, raising a total of £8.7bn from floats that have included estate agent Foxtons and the insurer Esure. For the whole of last year, London flotations raised £3.5bn via 46 issues.

Merlin, which also owns Alton Towers, the London Eye, and Warwick Castle, is perhaps best known in the UK as the owner of the waxworks museum on Marylebone road in central London, which traces its UK roots back more than 200 years. Madame Tussaud brought her exhibition on tour to Britain in 1802, and established The Baker Street Bazaar in 1835, while the attraction moved to its current site in 1884. It claims to have received 500 million visitors since its creation.

Despite the waxworks being widely known, Merlin's other brands are its biggest money earners. In total the company runs 99 attractions across 22 countries, taking £1bn in revenue last year from 54 million visitors and making £98m of profit. Of those venues, six of Europe's top 20 most visited theme parks are run by Merlin, according to analysts Aecom, three of which – Alton Towers in Staffordshire, Legoland in Windsor and Thorpe Park in Chertsey – are based in Britain.

Now the holding company is set to go public, valuing the 36% stake currently held by Kirkbi at about £1.2bn, Blackstone's 34% at £1.1bn and CVC's 28% at £900m, although the firms will be cashing in £600m worth of shares. Merlin was last valued in 2010 when CVC acquired its stake, and the whole business was worth £2.25bn.

Senior management and around 2,000 employees, who will end up owning about 8% of the firm are also preparing for windfalls, particularly chief executive Nick Varney, and finance director Andrew Carr who completed a private-equity backed management buyout of the company in 1999 to create Merlin. Since then the group has acquired the Tussauds Group, which also included Chessington World of Adventures and Thorpe Park, plus the Italian theme park Gardaland.

"Our destiny was always to be a public company," said Varney as he recalled a previous aborted effort to float his management buyout, plus a series of different private equity owners, including Apax and Hermes, before settling on the current shareholders. "Being bought every three years can be disruptive. Now is the time for long-term share ownership".

It is also the time to re-jig its corporate structure that means the company is based in Luxembourg. The exact tax that the company pays in the UK, therefore, is tricky to find, although the company seems to have realised that such arrangements have the potential of upsetting its customers. It plans to domicile the company in the UK after the float, when it is understood that its effective tax rate will move towards 28%.

A spokesman said: "Merlin Entertainments pays the correct level of tax in the countries, or jurisdictions, in which we operate, in relation to our capital structure".

On the flip side, however, there are those who argue Merlin has been a huge contributor to the UK economy. A spokesman for VisitBritain, the national tourism agency, said: "Merlin attractions have brought more than a million pounds in revenue so far this year to VisitBritain's shop and around 14% of our sales have come from the top-selling Merlin products. Our sales figures suggest that Merlin's attractions continue to attract overseas visitors, with numbers showing no signs of abating."

Of the remaining flotation proceeds, around £200m will be used to reduce the group's debt, the company said, while the company also has unveiled expansion plans.

Next year Merlin will open a huge Madame Tussauds near Tiananmen Square in Beijing, while in the US there are plans for a Madame Tussauds and a "dungeon" for San Francisco, a Sealife Centre in Charlotte, North Carolina and a small indoor Legoland discovery centre in Boston.

Merlin plans to float up to 30% of its shares, with up to 15% targeted at members of the public. The group is also trying to tempt customers into buying the shares, by offering members of the public spending at least £1,000 on the shares a 30% discount for one year on theme park annual passes.

The discount has been dismissed as a gimmick by analysts – Merlin is currently offering the public a 25% discount on its website – but Varney insisted it was "a pretty good deal".

"We think that is a nice thing to offer to people who want to invest at a retail level," he said. "But the real reason to invest is to own a part of the company that owns Legoland, the London Eye and Madame Tussauds, which has got an expanding international footprint and a very strong growth trajectory."

webTitle: VW profits jump despite high German unemployment and falling prices

fields.standfirst: Car giant's improved fortunes say more about dire state of European auto market than a healthy business environment
fields.body:
News of a jump in profits at Volkswagen begs the question how it fits alongside higher German unemployment and falling prices in key German states.

First we should look at Volkswagen. The rise in profits by a fifth in the third quarter tells us more about the dire state of the European car market last year than it does of a healthy business environment in 2013. The improvement is also at the top end in the Porsche and Audi brands, which confirms the polarisation of consumers, with the rich still buying high-end models and middle income earners holding on to older cars. Europe's largest car maker is also aiming to freeze hiring while expanding production with a new modular platform for its small and medium-sized cars.

"We are focusing on disciplined cost and investment management," said the company's finance chief, Hans Dieter Pötsch. "That's particularly important given the fact that the economic environment isn't expected to improve in the short term."

And it's those difficult economic times to which we turn next. Unemployment has risen for three months in a row. The deterioration is only marginal and some analysts point to changes in the way the authorities account for trainees as the answer. Nonetheless, it is going in the wrong direction.

Also, inflation is falling in several key states. As Annalisa Piazza at Newedge Strategy points out: "So far, four German Landers released their preliminary CPI figures. Hesse and Brandenburg CPI came in at -0.2%, Saxony and -0.3% and – more importantly – Bavaria CPI fell by 0.4% m/m."

The forecast is for a flat reading in October and therefore a fall in the annual rate to 1.1-1.2% in October, down from 1.6% for the prior month.

Piazza says a combination of factors have pushed inflation down, including lower energy prices.

So efficiencies at Volkswagen, coupled with rising unemployment and a falling inflation rate are indicative of lacklustre demand. Just when Europe needs the German economy to drive growth, businesses embark on ever greater efficiency drives and all that entails. Maybe higher pay deals will increase demand, but at the moment, an uncertain world is encouraging firms to cut out even more fat from their organisation and workers to cut expenditure and save.

webTitle: Royal Mail workers call off one-day strike after talks progress

fields.standfirst: Union and management say new agreement will include an improved pay offer and separate pensions agreement
fields.body:
A strike planned by Royal Mail workers in the aftermath of the company's recent privatisation has been called off after unions and management said talks were progressing.

The Communication Workers Union (CWU) had given notice of a one-day strike by its 115,000 members in the postal service next Monday over issues including pay, pensions and the legal protections offered to employees.

However, in a joint statement issued on Wednesday afternoon, Royal Mail and the CWU said they had made progress in talks and committed to finalising an agreement in the next two weeks.

Workers had voted 4-1 in favour of industrial action in a ballot earlier this month, despite the company offering all staff a £300 bonus if they committed not to strike. Royal Mail had made an initial offer of an 8.6% pay rise over three years but an improved offer will now be made.

The new agreement will include legal protections for employees that extend beyond the current three years and a separate pensions agreement. According to the nine-point draft agreement, both parties also commit to "an agenda for growth underpinned by a culture of consensual change, timely decision making and industrial stability supported by alternative dispute resolution processes".

With controversial changes to the 500-year-old service being implemented, there was also a commitment to a "joint company/CWU charter shaping the ongoing values and principles of the Royal Mail Group".

Royal Mail agreed to extend the legal validity of the CWU's strike ballot until 20 November, giving the union the opportunity to still enact a strike if agreement is not finalised. But both parties pledged to "clear diaries to ensure all our efforts are focused on reaching an agreement by 13 November".

While Royal Mail staff will not be walking out, the 4,000 members of the CWU who work in the 372 crown post offices are still due to strike on Monday, in a separate dispute over pay, branch closures and job cuts.

webTitle: Business blog: US Federal Reserve maintains bond buying programme - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
*Households under pressure as prices outstrip earnings
*Energy prices up 142% in a decade, says ONS
*Spain gets confirmation of recession exit
*German unemployment up by 28,000 on last year
*Markets expected Fed to hold steady on stimulus
fields.body:
6.19pm GMT

Closing summary

Time for a closing summary.

• The US Federal Reserve maintained its stimulus programme, as expected

• US jobs growth slowed unexpectedly

• European markets cautious ahead of Fed announcement

• UK households under pressure as prices outstrip earnings

* Energy prices up 142% in a decade, says ONS

* Spain gets confirmation of recession exit

* German unemployment up by 28,000 on last year

• Greece says it is owed €60bn in back taxes

And with that it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 6.20pm GMT

6.16pm GMT

Markets seemed faily unmoved by the Fed statement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down around 24 points, a slight improvement on the level before the announcement.

But US treasuries pared gains with some analysts suggesting the Fed's tone was more hawkish than expected. Omar Esiner, chief market analyst at Commonweatlth Foreign Exchange, said:

On balance, the Fed's statement was slightly less dovish than expected. What sticks out to me is that the Fed abandoned its previous statement about tightness in financial markets. [This] leaves room for the dollar to appreciate.

Eric Stein at Global Income Group said:

It's much as expected. Maybe a touch more hawkish. Treasuries sold off a little bit. The yen is weaker, dollar broadly stronger against major currencies.

Quotes courtesy Reuters.

6.09pm GMT

The Fed said that since its September meeting, economic activity continued to expand at a moderate pace. It said the labour market had shown some improvement but the unemployment rate remained high. The recovery in the housing sector slowed somewhat in recent months.

It believed, with appropriate policy accommodation, economic growth would pick up from its recent pace and the unemployment rate would gradually decline.

It decided to await more evidence that progress would be sustained before adjusting the pace of its purchases, hence it decided to maintain the bond buying programme at the current level:

The committee will closely monitor incoming information on economic and financial developments in coming months and will continue its purchases of Treasury and agency mortgage-backed securities, and employ its other policy tools as appropriate, until the outlook for the labor market has improved substantially in a context of price stability. In judging when to moderate the pace of asset purchases, the committee will, at its coming meetings, assess whether incoming information continues to support the committee's expectation of ongoing improvement in labor market conditions and inflation moving back toward its longer-run objective. Asset purchases are not on a preset course, and the committee's decisions about their pace will remain contingent on the Committee's economic outlook as well as its assessment of the likely efficacy and costs of such purchases.

To support continued progress toward maximum employment and price stability, the Committee today reaffirmed its view that a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy will remain appropriate for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends and the economic recovery strengthens. In particular, the committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and currently anticipates that this exceptionally low range for the federal funds rate will be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6-1/2 percent, inflation between one and two years ahead is projected to be no more than a half percentage point above the committee's 2 percent longer-run goal, and longer-term inflation expectations continue to be well anchored. 

The only member to vote against the action was Esther George, who was concerned that the continued high level of monetary accommodation increased the risks of future economic and financial imbalances and, over time, could cause an increase in long-term inflation expectations.

6.04pm GMT

Here's the full Fed statement.

6.01pm GMT

Fed keeps bond buying programme at $85bn

The US Federal Reserve has kept its monthly bond buying progreamme at $85bn, and make no change to its forward guidance on interest rates.

5.35pm GMT

Back in Greece prime minister Antonis Samaras is holding much-anticipated talks with his coalition partner Evangelos Venizelos amid mounting tensions ahead of next week’s forthcoming visit by officials representing the debt-crippled nation’s foreign creditors. Helena Smith writes:

Before it has even happened the arrival here on Monday of mission heads representing the EU, ECB and IMF is already being met with dread. Tonight’s meeting between Prime Minister Antonis Samaras and his deputy Evangelos Venizelos comes amid growing tensions with the country’s troika of foreign creditors as friction also mounts over how to plug a looming public funding gap estimated at €500m by the Greek government and closer to €2bn by the troika.

Officially, the ruling coalition – an uneasy alliance of conservatives and socialists with a wafer thin majority – is insisting that there can be no more budget cuts in a nation that long ago reached breaking point under the weight of austerity. Both politicians have repeatedly said that the demand for yet more cuts to make up for any deficit would be to tempt fate as the measures would almost certainly be voted down by MPs and the government would fall. Last week, in a first, the Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras raised the prospect of making up for the shortfall by tweaking social security funds – in itself an admission that measures, of some sort, would have to be made. The government’s only technocrat, the macro-economics professor said the policy of sticking to “no more measures” risked destroying Greece’s rescue program altogether – not least the promise of further debt relief down the line.

But his announcement was immediately met with consternation by other government ministers, including the Labour and social security minister who flatly ruled out further reductions to pensions in any form.

Stuck between a rock and a hard place the government has very little room for manoeuvre – if it doesn’t stick to the rules the regular injection of foreign cash that has kept bankruptcy at bay will simply dry up. Officially, tonight’s meeting is all about Samaras and Venizelos drawing up a ‘strategy’ that will prevent them straying over “red lines”. But the troika is playing hardball and has already hinted that with the numbers, once again, not adding up it will likely reject Stournaras’ plan. Black clouds beckon.

5.15pm GMT

European markets cautious ahead of Fed

European markets have closed, and after some early enthusiasm ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting a note of caution set in, partly due to poor American jobs data. Here are the closing numbers:

• The FTSE 100 finished up 2.97 points or 0.04% at 6777.70

• Germany's Dax dipped 0.13% to 9010.27

• France's Cac closed down 0.09% at 4274.11

• Italy's FTSE MIB ended 0.47% lower at 19,166.93

• Spain's Ibex slipped 0.86% to 9778.7

An hour or so away from the Fed announcement, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is virtually unchanged, down just 0.02%.

5.09pm GMT

So we move from the RDS and the Web Summit to the ornate 18th century splendour of Ireland's old Colonial parliament facing Dublin's Trinity College, writes Henry McDonald.

The Republic's Industrial Development Authority has organised a bash to celebrate the creation of 335 new hi-tech jobs on the same day at the Summit. The jobs will be spread between Dublin, Cork and Limerick, and include the likes of San Franciso based Nitro which is establishing its European beach head in Ireland. Nitro, the company behind PDF software like Adobe and Acrobat, have created 50 new posts in Dublin. Another North American company, the Canadian based firm, is also opening its EU HQ in the Irish capital with 30 new jobs. The largest number of jobs, 100 in total, is again the result of another technology firm, Adroll, opening a European base in Dublin.

Enda Kenny, the Irish premier, is here to officially announce the 300 jobs during a busy day which saw him ringing the NASDAQ bell at the Web Summit.

“Ireland remains one of the most exciting places in the world for new digital enterprises. I'm delighted to welcome 335 new jobs in nine companies in the rapidly growing digital sector,” he told the audience inside the marbled atrium of the old parliament that is also home to one of Ireland's taxpayer rescued banks, the Bank of Ireland.

4.00pm GMT

Over to Greece where the finance ministry has announced that it is owed almost €60bn in backtaxes. Our correspondent in Athens Helena Smith writes:

It has taken the Greek finance ministry itself to puncture the illusion that tax collection is anywhere near normal in the country. In a statement earlier today the ministry announced that unpaid taxes increased by €809m in September bringing the total amount owed by taxpayers to a €6.1bn so far this year.

Overall, it added, Greeks owed some €59.6bn in unpaid taxes to the state – the equivalent of nearly a fifth of the government’s debt and a drain on public finances like no other. Tax arrears in 2012, by comparison, came to around €56bn.

Greece’s chaotic tax collection machine has been the bane of troika officials since the start of the debt crisis with Athens under immense pressure to crack down on evaders. The latest losses come despite the government instituting an “emergency” property tax and a bevy of new tax laws – in the last two years more than 20 new tax laws have been enacted. The burgeoning hole is evidence of the counter productiveness of austerity – assaulted by the ever growing number of duties an ever growing number of Greeks, already hit by pension and pay cuts, have simply resigned themselves to not paying taxes at all.

3.56pm GMT

Markets are drifting lower now ahead of the US Federal Reserve announcement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average off 0.18% and the FTSE 100 down 0.11%. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

European markets continue to do their best impression of three steps forward and two steps back, hitting five year highs early this morning before sliding back in the wake of this afternoon’s disappointing US October ADP employment report.

Whatever the reasons for the positive start and subsequent pullback there does appear to be some element of profit taking amongst investors ahead of this afternoon’s FOMC meeting.

While today’s ADP numbers play into the argument that a taper remains some way off, there is a chance that the Fed could well be less dovish in its statement than markets anticipate. Given that the Fed wrong footed the market at the last meeting no one wants to be caught out by an unexpected curve ball.

Updated at 3.58pm GMT

3.40pm GMT

Here's a good chart from StockTwits showing global central bank stimulus - from the Federal Reserve, Europan Central Bank, Bank of England, Bank of Japan and Peoples Bank of China - at a record high.

Updated at 3.43pm GMT

3.25pm GMT

Unemployment is set to rise again in the US if the pace of jobs growth continues to erode, a top economist warned on Wednesday. My colleague Dominic Rushe writes:

Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Moody’s Analytics and a former adviser to presidential candidate John McCain, made his comments as ADP, the giant payroll provider, said the private sector added 130,000 jobs from September to October. ADP revised September’s job gain down from 166,000 to 145,000. Moody’s helps compile the closely-watched poll.

"The government shutdown and debt limit brinksmanship hurt the already softening job market in October. Average monthly growth has fallen below 150,000. Any further weakening would signal rising unemployment,” said Zandi.

Here's Dominic's full report:

US unemployment will rise unless jobs growth quickens, top economist warns

2.57pm GMT

Here's a look ahead to what the US Federal Reserve may say in its statement tonight, where reading the runes of the Fed's announcements is something of an art form. Nick Beecroft at Saxo Capital Markets said:

There is a non-trivial chance that the Federal Open Markets Committee will downgrade its assessment of the economic situation in the first paragraph of its statement today. The last meeting’s statement began thus:

Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in July suggests that economic activity has been expanding at a moderate pace.

and

Household spending and business fixed investment advanced, and the housing sector has been strengthening, but mortgage rates have risen further and fiscal policy is restraining economic growth.

Potential tweaks include a change from moderate to modest in the first sentence - a downgrade in assessment which it has employed previously. It would also be no surprise to see a more downbeat description applied to household spending. Last time, the second paragraph contained the following sentence:

The Committee sees the downside risks to the outlook for the economy and the labor market as having diminished, on net, since last fall,…

This sentence surely needs revision in light of the government shutdown/debt ceiling headwinds, maybe even to the extent of the replacement of ‘diminished’ with ‘increased’, or a synonym thereof, and maybe, ‘since the last meeting’.

Updated at 3.02pm GMT

2.36pm GMT

Another sign the eurozone may be edging its way out of trouble came from Belgium, where GDP grew by 0.3% in the third quarter compared to the previous three months, and up 0.4% year on year. Philippe Ledent at ING said:

Belgium is one of the first eurozone countries to deliver growth numbers for the third quarter.

The number released today can be considered as good news, and our 0.1% growth estimate for 2013 becomes more and more likely. Having said that, the overall economic outlook remains quite uncertain and we don’t expect any strong acceleration of growth in the near future.

The number released today for Belgium is also a good sign for the whole of the Eurozone. As Belgium is a very open economy, it is likely that the Belgian activity benefited in the third quarter from positive growth in the neighbouring partners, and mainly Germany.

Updated at 2.37pm GMT

2.30pm GMT

Eugene Kaspersky's warning that the next big cyber attack may be on national infrastructures was apposite given that he made it in Dublin today, writes Henry McDonald.

There is limited water supply at the Web Summit because of problems at one of the mai water plants that serve the Irish capital.

Restrictions on mains water have been imposed after technical dificulties at the Ballymore Eustace plant in Co.Kildare which caused supply to drop by up to 25%.

There is even the suggestion that recent heavy rain has made the reservoir water more difficult to treat at the plant.

Updated at 2.38pm GMT

2.17pm GMT

On Wall Street, markets are driftng higher as investors continue to bet that the US Federal Reserve will maintain its stimulus programme, especially given the disappointing jobs data earlier.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is up around 5 points in early trading while the S&P 500 has added around 2 points. Not much of a move, but enough to keep European markets in positive territory. The FTSE 100 has been flirting with the May high of 6840 - if it surpasses that the index will be at its best level since December 1999 - but is currently up 0.07% at 6779.35.

On the ADP jobs data itself, not only did the private sector add 130,000 jobs in October compared to an expected 150,000 but September's figure was revised down from 166,000 to 145,000. The figures came as the US government temporarily shut down over the political impasse on the budget. James Knightley at ING said:

This [fall] reflects the government shutdown and debt default fears, which clearly made corporates reluctant to hire. Indeed, many private sector firms with government contracts will not have been paid and may have been forced to lay-off staff while those not with government contracts will presumably have been concerned about the possible economic damage and delayed hiring.

Furthermore, the Federal Reserve Beige Book had suggested that “uncertainty surrounding the implementation of the Affordable Care Act” made firms more cautious on hiring. This is not good news for the BLS employment report, which has been delayed until 8 November, suggesting that the labour market is losing momentum. As such this adds further weight to the case for a delay in Federal Reserve asset purchase tapering.

Updated at 2.18pm GMT

1.55pm GMT

Kenny rings the NASDAQ bell

And here is an update from Henry McDonald on the New York tech-stock exchange opening in Ireland (see 9.40).

Enda Kenny rang the NASDAQ bell and made history as it was the first time the New York based tech-stock exchanged opened in Ireland.

After opening the NASDAQ at the Web Summit, the Irish premier told his audience that Ireland had become a "magnet for tech start ups" over the last few years.

He said the RDS arena was "full of energy, full of young, skilled, passionate people" who were driving the Irish tech industry.

The Taoiseach said: "We are the most open economy in the western world and we celebrate our pro business ethos and environment without hesitation....investment in Ireland is at record levels, business believes in Ireland. "

In a more heavily political aside, Kenny claimed his government had restored "trust and integrity" in Ireland throughout the world.

Later he will help launch a raft of new job announcements in the hi-tech sector at event organised by the Republic's Industrial Development Authority. 

With that, I'm handing over to my coleague Nick Fletcher.

Updated at 2.05pm GMT

1.51pm GMT

Cybercrime costs far exceed $100bn

The next cyberattack could look like Die Hard 4, putting vital infrastructure under threat. This is not Hollywood fantasy, but a real world risk, according to one of the world's leading experts in countering cybercrime, Eugene Kapersky.

Henry McDonald spoke to Kapersky at the Dublin WebSummit. Here is his report:

Eugene Karspersky, who built and owns the planet's largest cyber crime fighting lab based in Moscow, told the Guardian that the main threat to the economy and world security will be cyber-attacks on "critical infrastructures" such as power stations, national grids, factories and transport systems.

"I fear the next big attack in cyber space will be on critical infrastructures...if you have seen Die Hard 4 where this happens in the movie, it is no longer just Hollywood fantasy. It really could happen," he said. 

 Kaspersky also said that the costs of cybercrime far outweighed experts' best estimates. "The experts estimate that the damage from cybercrime to the global economy is estimated to be around 100 billion US dollars every year. That was said three years ago and I would guess it is far far in excess of that now. It's even worse today, it's times more that figure!"

Kaspersky said that he was rolling out a system with Microsoft across the world to teach children about cyber security and protection on the Internet. 

"From two years old kids are learning about the Internet so for the rest of the world we need to teach kids how to behave in the networks. It's like we teach kids how to behave on the street, how to cross the street safely, not to trust everyone. It is ethical as well as technical and it is non profit. It's actually technical later, the ethical bit comes first."

Updated at 1.51pm GMT

1.37pm GMT

Gold up on stimulus hopes

The price of gold has risen, after disappointing U.S jobs data (12.26) bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would not cut its stimulus later today.

Spot gold rose 1.1% to $1,358 per ounce, although has since dropped down a little. A weaker economy makes gold more appealing for investors.

1.25pm GMT

Jane Austen picture not on the money

Jane Austen banknote controversies are becoming as common as ineligible suitors in her novels.

Here is the latest: the Bank of England is under fire for choosing a "saccharine picture" of the author to put on the next £10 note. This comes after the bank displeased Austen scholars by blundering with the quotation on the bills.

Paula Byrne, a Jane Austen biographer, said the bank had made the "supreme social satirist" look like "a really cost middle-class writer".

 I think it is brilliant that she's on the note, it's just that it would have been better to show her as much more spiky, rather than suggest that she was a saccharine writer.

Judge for yourself here and vote for 'smiling' or 'unsmiling' here.

Updated at 1.28pm GMT

1.09pm GMT

Here is a report on those ONS cost of living numbers (10.23) from the Guardian's economics editor Larry Elliott:

Households spending bigger share of income on fuel and other essentials

12.53pm GMT

EU warns US debt row casting a shadow over world economy

The president of the European Commission José Manuel Barroso has told the United States to resolve its debt problems for the sake of its own credibility.

In an interview with Reuters, Barroso said the battle between Republicans and Democrats over the debt ceiling was casting a shadow over the global economy. It is certainly an interesting role reversal, after several years of lectures from the Americans about Europe's debt crisis.

Barroso also weighed in on the spying row, describing revelations of US spying on its European allies as "a very big surprise".

Here are some of the key quotes:

 What is at stake is fundamental, not only for the American economy, but also for the credibility of the United States in the world.

I hope that American democracy will work and will deliver what I think is critically important, not only for America but also for the world, because of the size and the impact of the American economy in the world.

"One of problems that (our) crisis highlighted, and a lesson we should draw, is the issue of confidence. We have a serious problem of confidence...Investors globally have been risk averse and this is not good for a scenario where we want globally to restore sustainable growth. Everything that casts a shadow over the confidence of investors is certainly not good, neither for the country concerned, in this case the United States, nor for the global economy.

[On spying] It's a matter of the utmost sensitivity. We believe it should be addressed in a way that gives reassurances that can build trust between the United States and Europe," he said."There is no more important relationship for Europe than the relationship with the United States, and I also believe there is no more important relationship for the United States than the one it has with Europe.

Updated at 12.58pm GMT

12.29pm GMT

US jobs slowdown - reaction

Updated at 12.58pm GMT

12.26pm GMT

US job creation slows

Hot off the press: new non-farm private sector jobs in the U.S grew at their lowest rate since April, according to a respected survey.

The ADP national employment report shows that 130,000 jobs were created in October, compared to 145,000 jobs the previous month. Since hitting 190,000 jobs in June, job creation has been drifting downwards, with the US shutdown rattling people's nerves about the health of the economy.

Updated at 12.26pm GMT

12.12pm GMT

Bank of England bids for balanced UK recovery

The governor of the Bank of England Mark Carney has said he will use all the tools at his disposal to tackle uneven growth across the country.

In an interview with the Western Mail, he said other parts of the country were not yet seeing the same pick-up in the economy as London.

It is quite different across different parts of the United Kingdom and there isn’t that momentum yet here in Wales, certainly nothing compared to what’s happening in the centre of London.

 We’re now better placed with a broader set of tools [so] that if there are imbalances that are building in some parts of the economy, whether it’s a sector such as housing or some regions, we can to a degree help lean against those so that we don’t use our broadest tool, which is monetary policy, to try to attack a specific issue in a specific part of the country but end up affecting other important regions and home nations such as Wales.

Also worth noting that he rebutted the idea that the size of the public sector - a bogeyman for centre-right economists - might be holding back the recovery in Wales.

The recovery is going to be driven by the private sector, whether it’s in Wales or across the UK. I wouldn’t characterise it as being held back by the public sector, it’s a question of further expansion of the private sector. 

You can read the full interview here

Updated at 12.14pm GMT

11.52am GMT

German unemployment at 2-yr high

Earlier we reported on a surprise jump in German unemployment, via the German Statistics Agency (8.18).

For the record, the Labour Office also has employment data out today, which tells the same story with a different set of figures.

According to the Labour Office, the number of people out of work increased by 2,000 to 2.9m in September, the highest level since June 2011. This was worse than economists had forecast and will add to fears that Europe's largest economy is slowing down. The jobless rate held steady at 6.9%.

But Anatoli Annenkov, senior economist at Societe Generale SA, told Bloomberg that things could get better.

Survey indicators are weakening a bit and the big concern that we have is that even German companies are not investing that much....If we have continued growth in the third and fourth quarter, we can start to look forward to continued improvement in the labour market.

Updated at 11.52am GMT

11.32am GMT

Irish drinks company finds recovery in the pub

Irish consumers are returning to the country's pubs again, according to company behind Magners and Bulmers cider.

C&C said sales volumes in bars had out-performed off-licences for the first time in seven years and reported a 7.9% increase in profit.

Chief executive Stephen Glancey said new pubs were opening in Ireland after a difficult decade for the sector.

The encouraging thing for us is that over the summer when the sun shone, that would normally send people back into the supermarkets to drink at home and have barbecues, and actually they went to the pub so it could well be the turning point.

Having been bearish for two or three years on Ireland in terms of the economic cycle, we're bullish. The Irish consumer is certainly feeling a lot better. That's fundamentally very good news for us.

Quotes from Reuters.

10.58am GMT

The TUC has not been slow in responding to the ONS report, which shows the rising cost of essentials for households.

 Frances O’Grady, TUC general secretary, says the government "must wake up and start tackling the cost of living crisis".

Today’s figures confirm that households are not benefitting from the recovery.

Growth matters because it raises people’s living standards. But this basic rule has been broken under an austerity-obsessed government. Most people will not feel as if we are in recovery if all the gains from growth are hogged by the same old elites, at the cost of ordinary families.

The ONS report also shows the scale of our cost of living crisis, with people now having to spend more than a third of their incomes on essentials as they suffer the longest wage squeeze in over a century.

The government must wake up and start tackling our cost of living crisis. It can start by taking on the excessive profits of the big energy firms that have pushed energy bills up so much that households are now spending more on gas and electricity than they are on filling up the car.

10.51am GMT

Here are more highlights from the ONS survey, via Twitter:

Updated at 11.11am GMT

10.23am GMT

Cost of living pressures mount

More evidence of the strain on UK household finances over the last few years, from the Office for National Statistics this morning.

In its monthly economic review, the ONS draws attention to pressure on household budgets. Here are some of the headlines that have jumped out:

  • The ONS finds "little evidence of a sustained improvement in the economic position of households",with Real Households’ Disposable Income (RHDI) static since 2009, despite GDP growth of 4.2% over this period.
  • Households are spending a higher proportion of their income on gas and electricity, 3.1% in 2013, compared t0 1.8% a decade ago.
  • The cost of housing is also up significantly, swallowing just over fifth of household income, compared to 14.7% in 2003.
  • The report also contains a reminder that while the economy is stronger, output is 2.6% below its 2007 peak, while manufacturing is 9% below its peak.

Read the full ONS economic review here

Updated at 10.51am GMT

9.55am GMT

Energy firms accused of acting "like a cartel"

The big six energy firms face further accusations of ripping off customers and acting "like a cartel" from a smaller competitor, following yesterday's bruising encounter with MPs. 

Dale Vince, chief executive of Ecotricity, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme, that wholesale costs alone could not justify the increase in bills. 

[The big six] have cited three factors: the rising cost of wholesale fossil fuels, government levies and the cost of distribution. All three of those are valid, in the case of wholesale price rises right now, if you look back over 12 months, then they are not justified in raising their retail prices because of wholesale movements in this year. 
Asked whether the firms were "ripping us off", he said:

I think there's been a degree of that going on ever since privatisation back in the early '90s.

Vince also rejected calls for an inquiry by the competition commission into the big six - as proposed by Tony Cocker of E.ON.

I don't think you need an inquiry to tell you this market is dysfunctional, you just have to look at it. Six big players have a 95% market share and they seem to operate like a cartel, the prices go up in conjunction. Privatisation in the energy sector has simply failed.

All quotes from PA

Updated at 10.51am GMT

9.40am GMT

NASDAQ comes to Dublin

A little bit of New York comes to Dublin today, with the opening of the NASDAQ stock exchange in the Irish capital. It won't all be razzmatazz. Ireland's prime minister will later face questions over the country's European bailouts and its low corporate tax rate.

Here is this report from the Guardian's Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald: 

For the first time in its history the NASDAQ stock exchange will open up in Dublin later today.
Ireland's prime minister Enda Kenny will ring the NASDAQ bell in the city's RDS conference centre as part of an international Web Summit taking place in the Irish capital. Up to 10,000 technology leaders, entrepreneurs and innovators are flocking to Dublin for the event which is estimated will inject €24 million into the city. 

Later today there will be a series of new job announcements and towards the close of play Kenny will be quizzed by the international media on the key questions over Ireland's economic future: the Republic expected exiting of the bail out from the IMF, EU and ECB rescue programme; the threat to the country's low corporation tax from Germany especially the Social Democrats who want the rate on the EU agenda as part of Coalition negotiations with Angela Merkel and another future international aid to prop up the state's still debt ridden banking system. 

Updated at 10.51am GMT

9.26am GMT

The next big banking scandal?

It sounds like 2008 all over again, with banks being hit by a string of misconduct investigations. Today Barclays has revealed it is ensnared in the probe into rigging £3 trillion a day currency markets, after regulators caught up with UBS and Deutsche Bank yesterday.

The Guardian's city editor Jill Treanor writes that the investigations could be on the scale of the Libor scandal.

In disclosing that it has received requests for information about its foreign exchange activities, Barclays is joining a number of other banks – including Royal Bank of Scotland, Deutsche Bank and UBS – admitting to cooperating with the authorities and also shedding light on the nature of the investigation that includes regulators in the UK, the US and Asia.

Barclays said regulators were investigating foreign exchange trade trading "including possible attempts to manipulate certain benchmark currency exchange rates or engage in other activities that would benefit their trading positions".

The investigations are at an early stage and could be on the scale of the Libor scandal, in which Barclays was the first bank to fined, in June 2012, with a penalty of £290m. That led to the departure of its chief executive, Bob Diamond, and the promotion of the retail banking head, Antony Jenkins, who has embarked on a strategy to restore the reputation of the bank.

The full story: Barclays cooperating with investigation into manipulation of currency markets

Updated at 10.51am GMT

8.59am GMT

Falling prices in Spain

Another important set of data from the statistics agency shows that deflation has come to Spain, with the consumer price index running at -0.1% for June to September.

Updated at 10.51am GMT

8.48am GMT

Spain out of recession

Now its official: Spain's economy has grown again for the first time since 2011, according to data from the National Statistics Institute.

Spain's gross domestic product grew by 0.1% between June and September, INE said, confirming last week's numbers from the Bank of Spain.

No breakdown of the figures is so far available (in English), but according to Reuters' man in Madrid, the economy seems to have been helped by exports and a busy tourist season, as travellers stayed away from troubled regions in the Middle East and north Africa.

None of this is likely to be much consolation to the millions out of work - Spain has an unemployment rate of 26%, one of the highest in Europe.

Ben May of Capital Economics thinks that weak domestic demand is likely to hold back recovery.

The upshot is that while economic prospects are considerably better than a year ago, particularly in the external sector, domestic weakness is like to hold back any recovery in the wider economy. We are pencilling in a below consensus 0.5% contraction in GDP next year. Based on this, we expect the unemployment rate to remain around its current high levels for some time yet and public debt to continue to climb.

Updated at 10.51am GMT

8.33am GMT

European markets round-up

European markets have edged up this morning, on strong company results and expectations that the Fed will leave its stimulus programme unchanged. 

FTSE 100 + 0.44% at 6,804 points

FTSEurofirst 300 +0.34% at 1,293 points

CAC 40 +0.06% at 4,280 points

Dax +0.11% at 9,031 points

FTSE MIB +0,46% at 19,349 points

Updated at 11.15am GMT

8.18am GMT

German jobless total rises

German unemployment has jumped by 1.4% since last year, according to data from the Federal Statistics Office.

The number of people in work was 42.1 million in September, the highest number since German reunification in 1990. But unemployment was 2.2 m in September, an increase of 28,000 people on last year. This leaves the unemployment rate at 5.2%.

Updated at 11.39am GMT

8.08am GMT

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

Investors are back on stimulus watch today, with the Federal Reserve expected to leave its $85 billion a month bond buying programme intact, when policymakers conclude their meeting today. With the exception of France's CAC 40, European markets opened slightly up this morning, after US indices hit record highs on Tuesday.

The consensus is for no change at the Fed, although Ilya Spivak, currency strategist at Forex Markets, thinks that the status quo could still cause ripples in markets.

 Broadly unchanged Fed commentary may be seen as comparatively hawkish considering investors seem primed for a noticeable lurch toward the accommodative side of the spectrum.

Plenty more is afoot today, with figures from Spain expected to confirm last week's data that the economy is growing for the first time since 2011. Figures just released show that German employment was steady in September. 

There are also lots of corporate results out this morning, with Barclays announcing a big jump in profits. I’ll also be rounding up reactions to Tuesday’s encounter between MPs and energy company bosses and tracking all the latest throughout the day...

Updated at 8.11am GMT
fields.bodyText: Time for a closing summary. • The US Federal Reserve maintained its stimulus programme, as expected • US jobs growth slowed unexpectedly • European markets cautious ahead of Fed announcement • UK households under pressure as prices outstrip earnings * Energy prices up 142% in a decade, says ONS * Spain gets confirmation of recession exit * German unemployment up by 28,000 on last year • Greece says it is owed €60bn in back taxes And with that it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back tomorrow. Markets seemed faily unmoved by the Fed statement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down around 24 points, a slight improvement on the level before the announcement. But US treasuries pared gains with some analysts suggesting the Fed's tone was more hawkish than expected. Omar Esiner, chief market analyst at Commonweatlth Foreign Exchange, said: On balance, the Fed's statement was slightly less dovish than expected. What sticks out to me is that the Fed abandoned its previous statement about tightness in financial markets. [This] leaves room for the dollar to appreciate. Eric Stein at Global Income Group said: It's much as expected. Maybe a touch more hawkish. Treasuries sold off a little bit. The yen is weaker, dollar broadly stronger against major currencies. Quotes courtesy Reuters. The Fed said that since its September meeting, economic activity continued to expand at a moderate pace. It said the labour market had shown some improvement but the unemployment rate remained high. The recovery in the housing sector slowed somewhat in recent months. It believed, with appropriate policy accommodation, economic growth would pick up from its recent pace and the unemployment rate would gradually decline. It decided to await more evidence that progress would be sustained before adjusting the pace of its purchases, hence it decided to maintain the bond buying programme at the current level: The committee will closely monitor incoming information on economic and financial developments in coming months and will continue its purchases of Treasury and agency mortgage-backed securities, and employ its other policy tools as appropriate, until the outlook for the labor market has improved substantially in a context of price stability. In judging when to moderate the pace of asset purchases, the committee will, at its coming meetings, assess whether incoming information continues to support the committee's expectation of ongoing improvement in labor market conditions and inflation moving back toward its longer-run objective. Asset purchases are not on a preset course, and the committee's decisions about their pace will remain contingent on the Committee's economic outlook as well as its assessment of the likely efficacy and costs of such purchases. To support continued progress toward maximum employment and price stability, the Committee today reaffirmed its view that a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy will remain appropriate for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends and the economic recovery strengthens. In particular, the committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and currently anticipates that this exceptionally low range for the federal funds rate will be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6-1/2 percent, inflation between one and two years ahead is projected to be no more than a half percentage point above the committee's 2 percent longer-run goal, and longer-term inflation expectations continue to be well anchored. The only member to vote against the action was Esther George, who was concerned that the continued high level of monetary accommodation increased the risks of future economic and financial imbalances and, over time, could cause an increase in long-term inflation expectations. Here's the full Fed statement. The US Federal Reserve has kept its monthly bond buying progreamme at $85bn, and make no change to its forward guidance on interest rates. Back in Greece prime minister Antonis Samaras is holding much-anticipated talks with his coalition partner Evangelos Venizelos amid mounting tensions ahead of next week’s forthcoming visit by officials representing the debt-crippled nation’s foreign creditors. Helena Smith writes: Before it has even happened the arrival here on Monday of mission heads representing the EU, ECB and IMF is already being met with dread. Tonight’s meeting between Prime Minister Antonis Samaras and his deputy Evangelos Venizelos comes amid growing tensions with the country’s troika of foreign creditors as friction also mounts over how to plug a looming public funding gap estimated at €500m by the Greek government and closer to €2bn by the troika. Officially, the ruling coalition – an uneasy alliance of conservatives and socialists with a wafer thin majority – is insisting that there can be no more budget cuts in a nation that long ago reached breaking point under the weight of austerity. Both politicians have repeatedly said that the demand for yet more cuts to make up for any deficit would be to tempt fate as the measures would almost certainly be voted down by MPs and the government would fall. Last week, in a first, the Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras raised the prospect of making up for the shortfall by tweaking social security funds – in itself an admission that measures, of some sort, would have to be made. The government’s only technocrat, the macro-economics professor said the policy of sticking to “no more measures” risked destroying Greece’s rescue program altogether – not least the promise of further debt relief down the line. But his announcement was immediately met with consternation by other government ministers, including the Labour and social security minister who flatly ruled out further reductions to pensions in any form. Stuck between a rock and a hard place the government has very little room for manoeuvre – if it doesn’t stick to the rules the regular injection of foreign cash that has kept bankruptcy at bay will simply dry up. Officially, tonight’s meeting is all about Samaras and Venizelos drawing up a ‘strategy’ that will prevent them straying over “red lines”. But the troika is playing hardball and has already hinted that with the numbers, once again, not adding up it will likely reject Stournaras’ plan. Black clouds beckon. European markets have closed, and after some early enthusiasm ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting a note of caution set in, partly due to poor American jobs data. Here are the closing numbers: • The FTSE 100 finished up 2.97 points or 0.04% at 6777.70 • Germany's Dax dipped 0.13% to 9010.27 • France's Cac closed down 0.09% at 4274.11 • Italy's FTSE MIB ended 0.47% lower at 19,166.93 • Spain's Ibex slipped 0.86% to 9778.7 An hour or so away from the Fed announcement, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is virtually unchanged, down just 0.02%. So we move from the RDS and the Web Summit to the ornate 18th century splendour of Ireland's old Colonial parliament facing Dublin's Trinity College, writes Henry McDonald. The Republic's Industrial Development Authority has organised a bash to celebrate the creation of 335 new hi-tech jobs on the same day at the Summit. The jobs will be spread between Dublin, Cork and Limerick, and include the likes of San Franciso based Nitro which is establishing its European beach head in Ireland. Nitro, the company behind PDF software like Adobe and Acrobat, have created 50 new posts in Dublin. Another North American company, the Canadian based firm, is also opening its EU HQ in the Irish capital with 30 new jobs. The largest number of jobs, 100 in total, is again the result of another technology firm, Adroll, opening a European base in Dublin. Enda Kenny, the Irish premier, is here to officially announce the 300 jobs during a busy day which saw him ringing the NASDAQ bell at the Web Summit. “Ireland remains one of the most exciting places in the world for new digital enterprises. I'm delighted to welcome 335 new jobs in nine companies in the rapidly growing digital sector,” he told the audience inside the marbled atrium of the old parliament that is also home to one of Ireland's taxpayer rescued banks, the Bank of Ireland. Over to Greece where the finance ministry has announced that it is owed almost €60bn in backtaxes. Our correspondent in Athens Helena Smith writes: It has taken the Greek finance ministry itself to puncture the illusion that tax collection is anywhere near normal in the country. In a statement earlier today the ministry announced that unpaid taxes increased by €809m in September bringing the total amount owed by taxpayers to a €6.1bn so far this year. Overall, it added, Greeks owed some €59.6bn in unpaid taxes to the state – the equivalent of nearly a fifth of the government’s debt and a drain on public finances like no other. Tax arrears in 2012, by comparison, came to around €56bn. Greece’s chaotic tax collection machine has been the bane of troika officials since the start of the debt crisis with Athens under immense pressure to crack down on evaders. The latest losses come despite the government instituting an “emergency” property tax and a bevy of new tax laws – in the last two years more than 20 new tax laws have been enacted. The burgeoning hole is evidence of the counter productiveness of austerity – assaulted by the ever growing number of duties an ever growing number of Greeks, already hit by pension and pay cuts, have simply resigned themselves to not paying taxes at all. Markets are drifting lower now ahead of the US Federal Reserve announcement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average off 0.18% and the FTSE 100 down 0.11%. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said: European markets continue to do their best impression of three steps forward and two steps back, hitting five year highs early this morning before sliding back in the wake of this afternoon’s disappointing US October ADP employment report. Whatever the reasons for the positive start and subsequent pullback there does appear to be some element of profit taking amongst investors ahead of this afternoon’s FOMC meeting. While today’s ADP numbers play into the argument that a taper remains some way off, there is a chance that the Fed could well be less dovish in its statement than markets anticipate. Given that the Fed wrong footed the market at the last meeting no one wants to be caught out by an unexpected curve ball. Here's a good chart from StockTwits showing global central bank stimulus - from the Federal Reserve, Europan Central Bank, Bank of England, Bank of Japan and Peoples Bank of China - at a record high. Unemployment is set to rise again in the US if the pace of jobs growth continues to erode, a top economist warned on Wednesday. My colleague Dominic Rushe writes: Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Moody’s Analytics and a former adviser to presidential candidate John McCain, made his comments as ADP, the giant payroll provider, said the private sector added 130,000 jobs from September to October. ADP revised September’s job gain down from 166,000 to 145,000. Moody’s helps compile the closely-watched poll. "The government shutdown and debt limit brinksmanship hurt the already softening job market in October. Average monthly growth has fallen below 150,000. Any further weakening would signal rising unemployment,” said Zandi. Here's Dominic's full report: US unemployment will rise unless jobs growth quickens, top economist warns Here's a look ahead to what the US Federal Reserve may say in its statement tonight, where reading the runes of the Fed's announcements is something of an art form. Nick Beecroft at Saxo Capital Markets said: There is a non-trivial chance that the Federal Open Markets Committee will downgrade its assessment of the economic situation in the first paragraph of its statement today. The last meeting’s statement began thus: Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in July suggests that economic activity has been expanding at a moderate pace. and Household spending and business fixed investment advanced, and the housing sector has been strengthening, but mortgage rates have risen further and fiscal policy is restraining economic growth. Potential tweaks include a change from moderate to modest in the first sentence - a downgrade in assessment which it has employed previously. It would also be no surprise to see a more downbeat description applied to household spending. Last time, the second paragraph contained the following sentence: The Committee sees the downside risks to the outlook for the economy and the labor market as having diminished, on net, since last fall,… This sentence surely needs revision in light of the government shutdown/debt ceiling headwinds, maybe even to the extent of the replacement of ‘diminished’ with ‘increased’, or a synonym thereof, and maybe, ‘since the last meeting’. Another sign the eurozone may be edging its way out of trouble came from Belgium, where GDP grew by 0.3% in the third quarter compared to the previous three months, and up 0.4% year on year. Philippe Ledent at ING said: Belgium is one of the first eurozone countries to deliver growth numbers for the third quarter. The number released today can be considered as good news, and our 0.1% growth estimate for 2013 becomes more and more likely. Having said that, the overall economic outlook remains quite uncertain and we don’t expect any strong acceleration of growth in the near future. The number released today for Belgium is also a good sign for the whole of the Eurozone. As Belgium is a very open economy, it is likely that the Belgian activity benefited in the third quarter from positive growth in the neighbouring partners, and mainly Germany. Eugene Kaspersky's warning that the next big cyber attack may be on national infrastructures was apposite given that he made it in Dublin today, writes Henry McDonald. There is limited water supply at the Web Summit because of problems at one of the mai water plants that serve the Irish capital. Restrictions on mains water have been imposed after technical dificulties at the Ballymore Eustace plant in Co.Kildare which caused supply to drop by up to 25%. There is even the suggestion that recent heavy rain has made the reservoir water more difficult to treat at the plant. On Wall Street, markets are driftng higher as investors continue to bet that the US Federal Reserve will maintain its stimulus programme, especially given the disappointing jobs data earlier. webTitle: Barclays' internal investigation results still to be revealed

fields.standfirst: The bank has yet to announce the outcome of its own reviews, but is now co-operating with a global currency probe
fields.body:
A year ago, when Barclays' investment bank boss Rich Ricci was still at the bank, and part of the clean-up operation following the Libor fine, he told parliamentarians on the banking standards committee that the bank was looking at the integrity of 80 financial instruments and benchmarks where it was involved in setting prices. These were potential places where prices could be manipulated.

The review was going on across the organisation and while it was continuing those areas were being placed under "heightened supervision", he told the commission.

It is not completely clear which markets and indices Barclays' "root and branch review" covered, but Ricci appears to have been referring to indices where formal prices were submitted, rather than foreign exchange markets. A year on Barclays is admitting that it is co-operating with a global investigation into currency markets that have a colossal £3tn a day of turnover.

The bank did not want to add any detail to the legal disclosures made in the third quarter figures and clearly co-operating with regulators does not imply any wrongdoing. Neither does setting up the review into foreign exchange trading. It would be interesting to know, though, what the outcome was of those scores of other reviews.

webTitle: FTSE 100 nervous ahead of US Federal Reserve meeting

fields.standfirst: Leading shares head towards new peaks before slipping back on US caution
fields.body:
Leading shares flirted with levels not seen since May, and came close to a 13 year high, before slipping back on nervousness ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting.

The FTSE 100 climbed as high as 6819, around 21 points shy of May's high and 22 off its best level since December 1999, buoyed by hopes the FED would continue its $85bn a month bond buying programme.

Some caution set in, however, especially after poor ADP jobs figures for October raised further concerns about the state of the US economy, QE or no QE.

In the end the FTSE 100 finished at 6777.70, up just 2.97 points.

Retailers were in demand after upbeat results from Next.

The high street and directories business reported better than expected third quarter sales up 4.3% and raised its full year profit guidance from £635m-£675m to £650m-£680m. It said trading had been volatile, with directory sales up 10.7% and store sales up 0.4%.

Next shares jumped 245p to £54.50, making them the best performer in the leading index, while rival Marks & Spencer added 7.6p to 493.2p and Debenhams rose 2.1p to 101.1p.

Others to update the market included Barclays, 2.4p better at 268.45p, and Pearson, down 49p at £13.16, and Standard Life, 14.7p lower at 354.5p.

Pearson said its 2013 profits would be down on last year, partly due to weaker demand for textbooks from north American schools, while Standard Life's third quarter sales came short of expectations.

But Tullow Oil saw its shares regain some ground after a poor couple of days.

After temporarily suspended drilling operations in northern Kenya following local demonstrations, a field in the Norwegian Arctic where Tullow has a 20% stake came up with a dry well which will now be plugged and abandoned.

But on Wednesday Tullow added 11p to 947p as Investec raised its rating on the group from sell to hold, saying the downside was limited in the near term.

Petrofac put on 10p to £14.78 as the oil and gas services business unveiled a $650m contract to extend the life of a gas field in Algeria, in partnership with Italy's Bonatti.

AstraZeneca added 17.5p to £33.30 ahead of its latest update due on Thursday, where analysts hope it may announce its new finance director.

The current incumbent, Simon Lowth, will leave after the announcement of the third quarter results to become finance director of BG Group (which happens to report figures on the same day).

Panmure Gordon analyst Savvas Neophytou said the figures themselves could well beat expectations and the unveiling of a new finance director would also be a positive move.

Among the mid-caps, Go-Ahead led the fallers, down 54p at £16.84, but only because the shares went ex-dividend.

Halfords was 2.6p higher at 415.4p after Barclays analysts raised their earnings forecasts and price target ahead of next week's first half results. The bank said:

We raise our second quarter estimates to reflect a good end to first half trading but expect management to join other retailers in commenting cautiously about the UK consumer into the second half. Sales have been steadily improving, helping investors' confidence on the name but any incremental buyers will already be looking into the second half, where most of the cost investment kicks in. We raise our earnings estimates by around 6%-7% and our target price by 9% to 360p but retain our equal weight rating as the shares are trading at an all time high valuation of 16.8 times 2014 PE.
We applaud management's initiatives to transform Halfords into a service led business but we are a bit more sceptical about the company's valuation. The market seems to believe that management's guidance is conservative but given that UK household income remains under pressure, we prefer to err on the side of caution.

Finally non-life insurer Gable edged up 0.375p to 62.625p after raising £10.7m by issuing shares at 55p to new and existing shareholders. The proceeds will be used to increase its available solvency capital as it looks for opportunities in new business classes. Analysts at Panmure Gordon raised their recommendation from hold to buy with a target price of 84p.

webTitle: US unemployment will rise unless jobs growth quickens, top economist warns

fields.standfirst: Latest ADP jobs report shows US added 130,000 jobs in October, with job growth weakened across most industries
fields.body:
Unemployment is set to rise again in the US if the pace of jobs growth continues to erode, a top economist warned Wednesday.

Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Moody’s Analytics and a former adviser to presidential candidate John McCain, made his comments as ADP, the giant payroll provider, said the private sector added 130,000 jobs in October. ADP revised September’s job gain down from 166,000 to 145,000. Moody’s helps compile the closely-watched poll.

"The government shutdown and debt limit brinksmanship hurt the already softening job market in October. Average monthly growth has fallen below 150,000. Any further weakening would signal rising unemployment,” said Zandi.

Zandi said job growth had weakened across most industries and company sizes. Small business growth, a major driver for employment, dipped from the previous month. The rate of job creation according to ADP has been decelerating since June when 190,000 jobs were created.

Job growth in goods-producing, construction and manufacturing rose in October. But hiring slowed dramatically for smaller firms. Businesses with fewer than 50 employees added 37,000 jobs in October, down from a gain of 68,000 in September. Hiring was also soft for firms with 50 to 499 employees; they added 13,000 jobs in October, compared to 18,000 in September. The pace of growth has dipped dramatically compared to the summer. Between June and August medium-sized firms added an average of 56,000 jobs per month.

In a note to clients, Capital Economics said the decline in jobs growth could have been attributable to wider factors than the government shutdown. “We’re not convinced that this latest easing was due to the government shutdown forcing private firms to cut headcounts. As the ADP counts the number of workers on payrolls, regardless of whether they were at work or paid, any private sector workers who were temporarily furloughed should still have been counted,” the economics group said.

Jobs growth has been slowing since the winter and the pace of recovery in the employment market is one of the weakest ever experienced after a recession. Private payroll numbers have grown for 44 months. But as of the end of September the US still has 1.8m fewer jobs than at the start of the recession. Long-term unemployment and the numbers of young people, African Americans and Hispanics looking for work remain alarmingly high.

ADP’s figures come as the Federal Reserve wrapped up its latest two-day policy meeting and left interest rates and its $85bn-a-month economic stimulus programme, known as quantitative easing, unchanged.
“The committee decided to await more evidence that progress will be sustained before adjusting the pace of its purchases," the Fed said in its statement.

On Tuesday US stock markets closed at record highs in anticipation that the Fed would not cut back on QE. On Friday policy makers will get snapshot of the jobs market when the Labor Department releases September’s nonfarm payroll figures, which include the number of government as well as private sector jobs created in the month.

webTitle: iPhone could be about to launch on China Mobile 4G

fields.standfirst: Apple may be about to fulfil ambition to expand into huge market as company reveals ad showing images resembling iPhones
fields.body:
China Mobile has advertised the launch of its 4G service next month, triggering speculation that Apple may have clinched a long-sought iPhone distribution deal with the world's largest mobile phone network.

Backing in the form of handset subsidies from an operator with over 700 million customers would be expected to push up the price of Apple. Forecaster ISI Group said the alliance could increase iPhone sales by more than 38m in 2014.

An advertisement has appeared on China Mobile's website featuring a cartoon tornado alongside the words "the invasion of 4G" and the date 11 November. Reuters reports the ad links to a page showing images of handsets resembling iPhones with the caption: "Special discounts for new handsets? The newest? The biggest discounts?"

Subsidised Apple handsets could help lure customers onto a network whose speeds will shortly be fast enough to exploit the full potential of 4G handsets.

11 November is "singles day" in China, a popular holiday on which young people celebrate their bachelor life and organise blind date parties. Popularised since the advent of the internet, it has also become one of the biggest shopping days of the year, with £2.4bn spent online last year according to McKinsey.

A deal with China Mobile would mark a successful conclusion to a long-held ambition for Apple, whose revenues from one of the world's largest markets rose just 6% in the three months to 28 September compared with the same period last year.

China already contributes £5.7bn in revenue a quarter to Apple, not far behind the $8bn (£5bn) earned from the entire European region, but the total could be much higher if Apple was to become one of the best selling smartphone brands in China.

The latest iPhones, the 5S and 5C, have already been approved by the Chinese authorities for use on these faster networks. Both Apple and China Mobile declined to comment.

webTitle: Spending by consumers using mobiles expected to triple in five years

fields.standfirst: Purchases on mobile phones and tablets likely to rise to £23bn, says Verdict
fields.body:
Shoppers will nearly triple the amount they spend via mobile phones and tablets over the next five years, taking the total to £23.1bn, according to the retail research firm Verdict.

Most of the increase will come as shoppers switch from laptops to mobile devices, though improving economic conditions and investment from retailers to encourage customers to buy from shop assistants wielding iPads will also help lift sales from an estimated £7.9bn this year.

Matthew Rubin, a Verdict analyst, said: "Mobile phone spend has grown rapidly, though it remains relatively small, while tablet spend has grown from nothing to almost twice the size of mobile phone spend in just the two years to 2012 and that trend has continued into 2013."

The launch of cheaper tablet computers, such as Tesco's Hudl and Argos's MyTablet, is also encouraging new types of shoppers such as less well-off over-55s to try out shopping using a mobile device, according to Verdict. Rubin suggested the move could drive a boom in sales of cheaper products via the internet, particularly clothing, which is proving to be particularly popular on tablets.

He said the switch could be a "major concern for retailers with a physical presence", but with only 7% of mobile phone transactions completed inside a store there was still plenty of opportunity to ensure sales were gathered by a traditional till.

Sales via mobile devices are expected to grow significantly this December as more people open presents containing iPads, Google's Nexus tablet computer or a Hudl on Christmas Day. More than half of the 8m tablets sold in Britain last year were bought in the last three months of the year. This year, more than 8m are expected to fly off the shelves up to Christmas. The change is driving a revolution in the busiest time for retailers, with spikes in mobile activity before breakfast and during the most popular evening TV shows.

webTitle: Households spending bigger share of income on fuel and other essentials

fields.bodyText: Households in Britain have seen their living standards stagnate for the past four years and are spending an increasing share of their incomes on "essentials" such as fuel and housing. The Office for National Statistics says households' true disposable income has flatlined since the end of the recession, in the autumn of 2009, even though national output has expanded by 4.2% over the same period. In a report likely to intensify the political row over energy prices, the ONS says the proportion of household income accounted for by essentials rose from 19.9% in 2003 to 27.3% a decade later. "The proportion accounted for by gas and electricity has risen from 1.8% in 2003 to 3.1% in 2013, despite very little overall change in the volume of household energy consumption," the ONS says. It adds that the weakness of real income growth – a measure of how much households have to spend once inflation is taken into account – has put pressure on budgets and limited the extent to which consumers can support growth by spending more. "Household budgets have been squeezed by recent increases in the price of household goods," the ONS said in its economic review, adding that demand for gas and electricity did not go down when prices went up. "As a result, the recent increases in the cost of energy have taken a larger share of disposable incomes." The ONS said recent movements in real household disposable income had followed the pattern of the recessions and recoveries in the early 1980s and early 1990s. In each case, an initial sharp drop in national output was not matched by a similar-sized fall in living standards because there was a lag before unemployment rose, cuts in borrowing costs helped mortgage payers, and increased welfare benefits helped stabilise the economy. As the economy subsequently recovered, household living standards rose more slowly than gross domestic product.
