webTitle: Small banks hope to phone in big earnings by luring customers online

fields.standfirst: Independence National Bank wants to compete with JP Morgan by investing millions into mobile tech. Will Americans log in?
fields.body:
Independence National Bank has a plan. The tiny Greenville, South Carolina-based bank, with $115.6m in assets, wants to be big on the internet.

More specifically, Independence wants to be big in mobile banking – an option usually not available to tiny banks that barely make a speck in JP Morgan’s shadow. Here’s why the bank's CEO, Gordon Baird, thinks his investment in mobile banking will pay off: it’s faster, cheaper and it will tell his customers immediately how much money they have, which may help them budget better. And the most important reason: in a world where the big boys in banking seem to get all the profits (and all the bailouts), moving to mobile banking may help his little bank survive.

“We believe that technology – some that we are developing on our own, as well as others that will soon be available on the market – can help community banks thrive and even compete with the larger more sophisticated institutions, both on cost as well as functionality,” says Baird.

It’s a big bet to move into mobile banking, and one that costs more than small-town money. Independence just hired two big tech dealmakers, former Verizon Wireless executives Aditya Khurjekar and Humphrey Chen, to move to South Carolina and help build its mobile technology and banking capabilities, after they helped grow Verizon’s 4G business.

Independence is spending $1.26m this year on its foray into mobile banking; the little bank just committed about $615,000 more to its expansion into the mobile banking business. So far, Independence’s mobile banking technology, which it plans to launch by the end of 2014's first quarter, costs the equivalent of 1.6% of the bank’s assets. For JP Morgan and Citigroup – which, admittedly, have been in the game longer –
technology spending amounts to only about 0.1% of their assets this year.

It’s ambitious, but it’s also an ambition Independence shares with many other banks. Mobile banking is the next hot thing, a way for banks to show that they’re striding confidently into the 21st century. According to spending forecasts for the year, consumer banks are increasing their information technology to $45.7bn, up 3.3% from 2012. The majority of the banks, or 57%, say that the increases will be dedicated to mobile banking, and another 46% are spending that money on online banking.

This is a sea change in what we think of as community banking. Community banks have long said that their strength is in personal relationships, that customers would rather have an account with someone they know. John Buhrmaster, President of First National Bank in Scotia, New York, says online banking helps customers keep their community bank accounts, even when they move away, and parents open accounts for their college-age children. As Buhrmaster catchily puts it, “When something goes wrong, who would you rather deal with: a 1-800 number or your community banker?”

It’s a good slogan, and Baird reinforces the point with hopes that mobile banking will increase foot traffic in his bank’s three branches. The only problem is that it rarely works out that way, or at least hasn’t so far. There’s no denying, industry-wide, that mobile banking often displaces face-to-face relationships.

Thanks to online banking, bank branches are less important, says David Wheelock, vice-president and deputy director of research at the St Louis Federal Reserve Bank. Banks close more branches as they herd their customers online, explained Nancy Bush, an analyst at SNL Financial. According to research by SNL, 2012 saw a nationwide loss of 1,118 branches, as banks closed 2,267 branches and opened only 1,149. Bank of America alone closed 256 branches while only opening 12.

For the big boys, the bet on mobile banking is paying off. Their growth numbers in mobile users look more like what you’d expect from a hot social media startup than a place where people stash their savings.

Here’s JP Morgan Chase crowing in its recent annual report about its mobile progress:

“At the end of 2011, Chase had 8.2 million 90-day active mobile users. At year-end 2012, we had 12.4 million active mobile users, a 51% increase in only 12 months. Today, we’re growing mobile users by roughly 350,000 a month."

There’s a reason that banks as divergent as Independence and JP Morgan are chasing online apps. A report, released last month by the Pew Research Center's Internet & American Life Project, found that 51% of American adults bank online. A smaller fraction of them, 32%, bank using their mobile phones.

For all the maudlin tributes to the warmth and power of community banking, most Americans seem to like their transactions digital. In fact, in 2012, the most common banking activities, like paying bills, viewing balances/statements and transferring money, are being conducted online about 60% of the time, found Forrester Research.

The only activity that seemed to still take place at an actual bank location was depositing a check, with 70% of check deposits still done in person. Banks are hunting that down too: Citibank, Charles Schwab, Chase and Bank of America all offer mobile deposits.

It’s all well and good when it’s about fees – and cutting costs – but in the world with hackers around every corner, banks are not totally secure. They still have to work on mobile security, because, as with the banks themselves, that’s where the money is.

"The financial services industry is one of the more attractive targets for cyber attacks, and, unfortunately, the threat is growing," said Thomas Curry, comptroller of the currency, in September. His office launched an effort to help banks strengthen their defenses.

Consumers are also reasonably wary of the risks of banking online or with their mobile devices. A survey conducted by the Federal Reserve found that 49% of consumers did not use mobile banking in 2012 due to security reasons. Among their concerns were hackers, losing their mobile device, and data interception by a third party; when the Federal Reserve surveyed consumers, 44% said their concerns included “all of the above”.

Still, Baird remains optimistic. If handled correctly, he believes that small banks can come out of “the transition to a more digital world” as winners.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer Christmas advert to be launched online

fields.standfirst: Glitzy promo featuring Helena Bonham Carter among its cast will first be shown on Facebook, YouTube and Twitter
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is to kick off its glitzy Christmas advertising campaign, on the theme of "Believe in Magic and Sparkle", via social media for the first time.

A teaser for the Alice in Wonderland-inspired ad, featuring Helena Bonham Carter and models David Gandy and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, will launch on Facebook, YouTube and Twitter on Wednesday before the full two-minute film goes live via the same channels next Monday.

Television viewers won't get to see Huntington-Whiteley dashing through a snow-sprinkled forest and riding a magic carpet in her lingerie until next Wednesday, during the Coronation Street advert break.

Patrick Bousquet-Chavanne, director of marketing & business development, said: "It's all about interaction and a conversation with our customers. Digital is the fastest way to be in that conversation and you are going to see us doing more of that."

As part of its interactive plan, M&S will ask viewers to vote via Twitter and Facebook on the name of the Highland Terrier that stars in the advert – they can choose between Magic or Sparkle. Footage of the dog taking shoppers on an adventure will also be released online.

Bousquet-Chavanne said the advert, directed by Johan Renck who has previously shot music videos for Madonna and worked with designer labels including Armani and Agent Provocateur, used universal tales including Alice in Wonderland and the Wizard of Oz, which would appeal in M&S's international markets including China and the Middle East, where it would also be distributed online.

webTitle: Barclays assisting with investigation into currency market manipulation

fields.bodyText: Barclays is involved in the new investigation by global regulators into the potential manipulation of the £3tn-a-day currency markets, in a fresh setback for the bank as it attempts to clean up its reputation in the wake of the Libor rigging scandal. As it published its third quarter financial results, Barclays disclosed that it has received official requests for information about its foreign exchange activities. Barclays is joining a number of other banks – including Royal Bank of Scotland, Deutsche Bank and UBS – in co-operating with the authorities and also shedding light on the nature of the investigation by regulators in the UK, the US and Asia. RBS said it was already reviewing its processes in the foreign exchange markets. Barclays also confirmed it is continuing to contest a £50m penalty from the Financial Conduct Authority for behaving recklessly in the way it raised funds from Qatar to avoid a taxpayer bailout in 2008. The foreign exchange investigations are at an early stage and could be on the scale of the Libor scandal. Barclays was the first bank to be fined for rigging the key interest-rate benchmark, in June 2012, and was handed a fine of £290m. That led to the departure of its chief executive, Bob Diamond, and the promotion of Antony Jenkins, who has since embarked on a strategy to restore the reputation of the bank through his so-called transform programme. Jenkins used the results to outline a vision for more technology at the bank – which, it is suggested, could lead to 40,000 job cuts – and said that he was embarking on a new review of the bank's 75 business lines to gauge the riskiness of the operations. Last month the bank was forced to tap shareholders for £6bn to bolster its financial strength. Jenkins said the new finance director Tushar Morzaria, who joined a fortnight ago, would reassess each business line to assess how much capital they are using. He refused to elaborate on the bank's legal disclosure that regulators are investigating foreign exchange trading "including possible attempts to manipulate certain benchmark currency exchange rates or engage in other activities that would benefit their trading positions". The bank said: "The investigations appear to involve multiple market participants in various countries. Barclays has received enquiries from certain of these authorities related to their particular investigations, is reviewing its foreign exchange trading covering a several-year period through August 2013 and is co-operating with the relevant authorities in their investigations." The investigations emerged after reports of allegations that traders at major banks were putting in client orders before a 60-second window when benchmarks run by WM/Reuters – and used by fund managers to value their investments – are set. Jenkins said his new team – as well as a new finance director, he has a new retail head and new bosses of the investment bank – needed to "push harder" in the final quarter of the year and into 2014. After being forced into the cash call by the Bank of England, Jenkins said the bank was continuing to "reassess the balance sheet for further leverage reduction opportunities consistent with preserving our strong franchises, supporting lending to the UK economy". When he took the helm he had originally assessed 75 business lines in terms of reputation risks and said he would withdraw from some businesses. The investment bank – the traditional powerhouse of the business and once known as Barclays Capital – took a hit to income as a result and also suffered a fall in its fixed-income trading. Third quarter profits in the investment bank fell 53% to £463m, although the bank did not disclose any reduction caused by shutting down the controversial tax planning department known as structured capital markets. Overall, in the third quarter, profits fell to £1.4bn from £1.9bn as losses in continental Europe widened. In the first nine months of the year Barclays's profits rose to £2.8bn from £962m, although this included the cost of buying back its own debt. The shares rose 3.5% to 274p in early trading. webTitle: Tullow edges higher after recent disappointments as Investec turns more positive

fields.standfirst: Oil group recovers from recent problems in Kenya and Norwegian Arctic
fields.body:
Tullow Oil has seen its shares regain some ground after a poor couple of days.

After temporarily suspended drilling operations in northern Kenya following local demonstrations, a field in the Norwegian Arctic where Tullow has a 20% stake came up with a dry well which will now be plugged and abandoned.

But now Tullow has added 14p to 950p as Investec raised its rating on the group. Analyst Brian Gallagher said:

With Tullow down 27% since Jan, we upgrade to hold [from sell], viewing downside as limited near-term. We are not ready to move to a buy as we don't believe Tullow's valuation case is compelling at current levels. Moreover, we feel that both Tullow's cashflow strength and exploration competency, while superior to peers, continues to be overstated and overvalued by the market. We flag two pending and possibly game changing exploration catalysts (Fregate in Mauritania and Tultule in Ethiopia) which could force us to reassess our neutral stance, if successful.

webTitle: Sainsbury's takes fight against Tesco Price Promise ads to judicial review

fields.standfirst: Supermarket chain mounts £150,000 legal challenge over adverts that claimed cheaper own brand goods
fields.body:
Sainsbury's is to take its fight against Tesco's Price Promise advertising campaign to a judicial review.

The legal challenge comes after the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) brushed aside Sainsbury's attempts to block ads by Tesco in which Tesco claimed a number of its own-label goods were cheaper than those of its rivals – including Sainsbury's.

Sainsbury's says the campaign misleads consumers because it fails to point out that many of Sainsbury's own-label products have superior ethical or provenance standards. Its claim is being supported by evidence from ethical trading accreditation bodies including Fairtrade, the RSPCA's Freedom Food initiative and the Marine Stewardship Council.

The commercial director of Sainsbury's, Mike Coupe, said: "We believe that all own-label products are not created equal."

Legal experts said the complaint to the ASA, subsequent appeal and the judicial review were likely to cost Sainsbury's about £150,000, and was more effective as a way to promote its own-label products than to halt Tesco's promotions.

Tesco's UK marketing director, David Wood, said: "A massive amount of work goes into making the comparisons, down to the quality of the individual ingredients, to make sure we make commonsense comparisons customers would see as fair and meaningful."

webTitle: AstraZeneca rises ahead of update and news on finance director

fields.standfirst: Analysts expect company to unveil replacement for Simon Lowth who moves to BG
fields.body:
AstraZeneca is moving higher ahead of its latest update due on Thursday, where analysts hope it may announce its new finance director.

The current incumbent, Simon Lowth, will leave after the announcement of the third quarter results to become finance director of BG Group (which happens to report figures on the same day).

Panmure Gordon analyst Savvas Neophytou said the figures themselves could well beat expectations and the unveiling of a new finance director would also be a positive move. He said:

We forecast revenues of $6.48bn, pretax profit of $2.16bn and core earnings per share of $1.39. The company provided consensus is for revenues of $6.35bn, pretax profit of $1.46bn and earnings per share of $1.24. Another trigger tomorrow might be the appointment of a new chief financial officer, with Simon Lowth's tenure coming to an end on 31 October. We do not expect an internal candidate to be announced.
We prefer an entry level closer to £30, but the shares seem attractive if we can see real signs of turnaround following a number of months of continuous downgrades.

Astra is currently 25.5p higher at £33.38.

webTitle: Next boosted by profit upgrade as FTSE climbs ahead of Federal Reserve meeting

fields.standfirst: Retailers rise after positive update as leading shares await Fed decision
fields.body:
As markets move higher in anticipation the US Federal Reserve will maintain its $85bn a month bond buying programme, retailers are in demand after upbeat results from Next.

The high street and directories business reported better than expected third quarter sales up 4.3% and raised its full year profit guidance from £635m-£675m to £650m-£680m. It said trading had been volatile, with directory sales up 10.7% and store sales up 0.4%.

Next shares have jumped 330p to £55.35, making them the best performer in the leading index, while rival Marks & Spencer is up 10.4p at 496p and Debenhams has added 2.2p to 101.2p. Freddie George at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

Over the last five years, Next's earnings per share has grown by 16% per annum. helped by positive momentum from the directory, which has achieved 18% per annum growth in trading profits over this period. The directory will continue to benefit from growth in the on-line market, an increase in customer numbers, a broadening of the ranges and the opportunity to develop overseas, in our view. These drivers coupled with the opportunity for the group to use it cash flows to buy-back shares will continue to lead to an improvement in return on invested capital and shareholder returns. The stock is trading on a 2014 PE of 16.4 times which is well supported by its superior returns and its on-line business when one considers the valuation the market puts on pure play retailers. We continue to prefer Nextf
to M&S and maintain our hold recommendation but upgrade our target price from 5,000p to 5,200p, reflecting the expected upgrade to consensus forecasts.

Overall the FTSE 100 has hit a new five month high, up 39.40 points at 6814.33. The key event for investors is the outcome of the latest Fed meeting, due at 6.00pm GMT. Most observers believe the Fed will hold fire on QE, with recent mixed data as well as the disruption caused by the US government shutdown and budget impasse. Joe Rundle at ETX Capital said:

[There has been a] perkier start for European financial markets on Wednesday following overnight strength in US and Asian markets as investors around the world appear to be confident that the Federal Reserve will keep the liquidity taps open by delaying tapering activity of the bond buying programme into 2014.
The poor run of US data continues, supporting the case for no tapering – on Tuesday, US consumer confidence fell to a six-month low, boosting risk assets. This month's government shutdown in the US also adds uncertainty given the potential damage to US economic growth. Furthermore, with the budget/debt battle to resume early 2014 in the US, the market feels relatively sanguine about QE sticking around longer than expected.

Others to update the market included Barclays, 9p better at 275.05p, and Pearson, down 46p at £13.19, and Standard Life, 13.1p lower at 356.1p.

Pearson said its 2013 profits would be down on last year, partly due to weaker demand for textbooks from north American schools, while Standard Life's third quarter sales came short of expectations.

webTitle: Joe Hockey says Coalition won't be held to ransom by the car industry

fields.standfirst: Treasurer takes tough public line despite Holden saying it needs certainty from the new government by Christmas
fields.body:
Joe Hockey has declared the Coalition will not be held to ransom by the car industry and says if Holden quits its Australian operations it will be Labor’s fault.

The treasurer adopted a tough public line on the day the government released its broad-ranging terms of reference for a Productivity Commission inquiry into the sector, which will report next March.

While that represents a fast-tracked inquiry, Holden has been saying publicly it needs certainty from the new government by Christmas.

But on Wednesday Hockey insisted the government would not be rushed. The treasurer told reporters in Melbourne while he did not want to see job losses: “We don’t negotiate with taxpayers’ money with a gun to our heads.

“We’ve got a responsibility to the entire Australian economy. We are not running down the street, chasing an individual car maker with a blank cheque. It’s got to be a partnership.

“If the car industry is in crisis, it’s Labor’s fault. This is not in our hands, there is a proper process in play – let’s work it through.”

That remark secured a quick retort from the shadow industry minister, Kim Carr. “The Abbott government is playing chicken with international car companies and risking the livelihoods of 200,000 Australians who depend on the automotive industry.”

Carr said the government was now in possession of the same information that had been provided to Labor by Holden about the state of its local manufacturing operations – and the same high-level advice from senior officials about appropriate actions.

He said Holden had briefed the Coalition as well as Labor last Christmas about its operations and the timeline required for future investment commitments. He contended delay in those circumstances represented “willful negligence”.

Hockey’s cabinet colleague, Ian Macfarlane, has been issuing public warnings since he took the industry portfolio after the lection of the knock-on consequences of another carmaker shutting down its Australian operations.

Macfarlane has said the repercussions of factory closures would be felt down the east coast of Australia. Ford has already announced its intention to quit local manufacturing.

Macfarlane appears to have been positioning himself ahead of future cabinet consideration to argue for a reversal of the Coalition’s pre-election policy, which was to reduce taxpayer funding for the carmakers by $500m. Macfarlane is now in Japan and will meet Toyota executives during his visit.

Carr told Sky News in regard to Holden: “The timelines are urgent and the government has failed to live up to its responsibilities.”

He said the Productivity Commission inquiry was a “ruse” to get the Coalition past the South Australian election. The timing of the final Productivity Commission report, he said, was two weeks after the state election.

The shadow industry minister said he was aware the board of General Motors had three weeks ago discussed the state of the Australian operation, and the mood had been “bleak”.

He said Holden had not, to his knowledge, taken a final decision to quit manufacturing in Australia, but the new government was making it difficult for the company to commit on an ongoing basis. Carr predicted if Holden pulled up stumps, Toyota would follow.
